TEXT: Thou sodden-witted lord! thou hast no more brain than I have in mine elbows.
I do bite my thumb, sir.
Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!
Go, prick thy face and over-red thy fear, / Thou lily-livered boy.
I do desire we may be better strangers.
There’s no more faith in thee than in a stewed prune.
Thou whoreson zed, thou unnecessary letter!
You are not worth another word else I’d call you knave.
You Banbury cheese!
I am sick when I do look on thee.
But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
The band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity.
That which I would discover / The law of friendship bids me to conceal.
Friendship is constant in all other things / Save in the office and affairs of love.
Thy friendship makes us fresh.
Keep thy friend / Under thy own life’s key.
I count myself in nothing else so happy / As in a soul remembering my good friends.
Most friendship is feigning, most loving is folly.
There is flattery in friendship.
The course of true love never did run smooth.
If music be the food of love, play on.
Speak low, if you speak love.
The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
There’s beggary in the love that can be reckoned.
A heart to love, and in that heart / Courage, to make’s love known.
Love sought, is good; but given unsought, is better.
Love looks not with the eyes but with the mind, / And therefore is winged Cupid painted blind.
Hear my soul speak: / The very instant that I saw you, did / My heart fly to your service.
Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.
Thou art sad; get thee a wife, get thee a wife!
For what is wedlock forced but a hell, / An age of discord and continual strife? / Whereas the contrary bringeth bliss, / And is a pattern of celestial peace.
Who wooed in haste and means to wed at leisure.
Marriage is a matter of more worth / Than to be dealt in by attorneyship.
The instances that second marriage move / Are base respects of thrift, but none of love.
Time goes on crutches till love hath all his rites.
Get thee a good husband, and use him as he uses thee.
If men could be contented to be what they are, there were no fear in marriage.
Fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to herrings, the husband's the bigger.
This above all - to thine own self be true.
We are such stuff as dreams are made on.
...it is not enough to speak, but to speak true.
But come what may, I do adore thee so that danger shall seem sport, and I will go.
...we know what we are, but know not what we may be.
Our doubts are traitors, and make us lose the good we oft might win, by fearing to attempt.
What’s past is prologue.
Let me be that I am, and seek not to alter me.
I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin…
For, being green, there is great hope…

Take but degree away, untune that string, And, hark, what discord follows. Each thing meets In mere oppugnancy. The bounded waters Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores And make a sop of all this solid globe…
And this our life, exempt from public haunt, Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
But I am now about no waste; I am about thrift.
And thorough this distemperature we see / The seasons alter…
All things are ready if our minds be so.
Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie, / Which we ascribe to heaven.
Nature craves / All dues be rendered to their owners.
I know a bank where the wild thyme blows, Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows, Quite over-canopied with luscious woodbine, With sweet musk-roses and with eglantine.
O, I have ta'en / Too little care of this.
The skies look grimly / And threaten present blusters.
Why, ’tis a happy thing / To be the father unto many sons.
I would my father look’d but with my eyes.
If by chance I talk a little wild, forgive me; I had it from my father.
My father's wit, and my mother's tongue, assist me!

To you your father should be as a god, / One that composed your beauties, yea, and one / To whom you are but as a form in wax, / By him imprinted and within his power / To leave the figure or disfigure it.
O, that our fathers would applause our loves, / To seal our happiness with their consents!
It is a wise father that knows his own child.
Who would be a father!
This tiger-footed rage.
Come not between the dragon and his wrath!
I understand a fury in your words / But not the words.
Anger is like / A full hot horse, who being allowed his way, / Self-mettle tires him.
Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot / That it do singe yourself.
Who is man that is not angry?
Let grief / Convert to anger; blunt not the heart, enrage it.
O, that my tongue were in the thunder's mouth! / Then with a passion would I shake the world.
Come not within the measure of my wrath.
There is no following her in this fierce vein.
To be, or not to be, that is the question.
All the world's a stage, / And all the men and women merely players.
Out, out brief candle! / Life's but a walking shadow, a poor player, / That struts and frets his hour upon the stage.
We are such stuff / As dreams are made on; and our little life / Is rounded with a sleep.
Be not afraid of greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.
When we are born we cry that we are come / To this great stage of fools
The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and ill together.
You cannot, sir, take from me anything that I will not more willingly part withal - except my life, except my life, except my life.
The time of life is short! / To spend that shortness basely were too long.
I love long life better than figs.
